Instead of outsourcing the work, he decided to learn what it would take to repair and keep up the real estate he owned himself. abstract: Friday was one of those days. I kept being disappointed by people I was trying to do business with. Am I doing something wrong?
snippet: Friday was one of those days. I kept being disappointed by people I was trying to do business with. Am I doing something wrong?
lead_paragraph: I’m not sure exactly what tipped me over the edge. Maybe it was the traffic on the way into work. Maybe it was the hour I wasted trying to get my printer to complete a scan over the wireless network. Or maybe it was just residual anger after receiving some shabby treatment from a colleague, a sales person and a job applicant — all of which led me to write a few honest e-mails to these malefactors. My first honesty-gram was directed at someone who owns a used furniture outfit nearby. He had asked me whether I could take a look at a damaged table that he had acquired and possibly repair and refinish it. Which led to the following exchange:

headline.main: Never Mind. I’ll Find Someone Else.

abstract: The European Parliament weighs how to regulate electronic cigarettes, while JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo kick off Wall Street’s third-quarter earnings season on Friday.
snippet: The European Parliament weighs how to regulate electronic cigarettes, while JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo kick off Wall Street’s third-quarter earnings season on Friday.
lead_paragraph: E-CIGARETTES The European Parliament, meeting in Strasbourg, France, plans to vote on Tuesday on a broad set of proposed tobacco regulations — the most contentious of which is how to regulate electronic cigarettes. Advocates of e-cigarettes say they are less harmful than conventional cigarettes, because users inhale nicotine-infused vapors instead of smoke. Despite the products’ growing popularity, some European public health officials want them regulated as medical devices. Even if tobacco industry lobbyists prevail in getting the European Parliament to back a less stringent form of regulation, the vote would be only a step in a European rule-making process for e-cigarettes that could continue into next year or beyond.

abstract: The BBC and the Discovery Channel are essentially dissolving a relationship that dates to the 1990s.
snippet: The BBC and the Discovery Channel are essentially dissolving a relationship that dates to the 1990s.
lead_paragraph: The BBC and the Discovery Channel are essentially dissolving a relationship that dates to the 1990s and delivered natural history programs like “Blue Planet,” “Planet Earth” and “Life” to American viewers. Some of the BBC’s wildlife documentaries and films will be co-produced by its cable channel BBC America instead of Discovery in the future, the British broadcaster said Wednesday. Discovery will continue to work with the BBC on some programs, but will also strike deals with other producers for science and natural history programs. The two collaborators have become more like competitors over the years. Discovery is increasingly an international brand, and it wants to have worldwide rights to its programming; meanwhile, the BBC wants to bolster its own branded channel in America. The two companies said they had mutually agreed to go their separate ways.

headline.main: BBC and Discovery Cut Back on Collaborations

abstract: Oct. 9 has twice been a turning point for stocks in this century. After the 2001 recession, the American market hit bottom on Oct. 9, 2002, and then peaked exactly five years later, on Oct. 9, 2007. American stocks underperformed most of the world during that five-year period, but have outperformed in the six years from 2007 to now. Within the United States, sectors that lagged in the earlier period have been strong more recently.

abstract: Over the years, Janet L. Yellen has occasionally been asked about being a female economist, providing a bit of insight into how she has viewed her rise in a male-dominated field.
snippet: Over the years, Janet L. Yellen has occasionally been asked about being a female economist, providing a bit of insight into how she has viewed her rise in a male-dominated field.
lead_paragraph: Last week, after President Obama nominated Janet L. Yellen, the Brooklyn-born, Brown-and-Yale-educated economist, to lead the Federal Reserve, commentators praised her intellect and expertise. But they were also quick to celebrate the fact that she would be the first woman to hold the top job at the 100-year-old central bank. Fairly typical was the sentiment expressed by Justin Wolfers, a University of Michigan economist, who wrote on Bloomberg View: “Tonight, I feel reassured that my daughter’s economic future is in good hands. I also plan to tell her that she, too, can grow up to become the most powerful economist in the world. It’s a potent stimulus.” Ms. Yellen seems more at ease speechifying in the realm of monetary policy and inflationary models than discussing her gender. But over the years, she has occasionally been asked about being a female economist, providing a bit of insight into how she has viewed her own rise in a male-dominated field.

headline.main: And Now, From the Woman Poised to Run the Fed ...

lead_paragraph: Investors in Cooper Tire and Rubber are being forced to pick lanes. lead_paragraph: The sum is worth more than the parts – auto parts, that is. Advance Auto’s $2 billion takeover of rival General Parts International resulted in the acquirer gaining $1 billion in market cap. That’s bang in line with the net present value of promised cost savings. Nobel Prize winner Eugene Fama’s efficient markets hypothesis may be flawed, but when it comes to the nitty-gritty of corporate finance, it often seems to work just fine.

lead_paragraph: RIVERSIDE, Calif. — It was 9:30 on a recent Tuesday morning at Manheim Riverside, a wholesale auto auction, and more than a thousand used-car dealers were mulling in the desert heat. The bidders had gathered on the perimeters of Manheim’s 10 lanes of cars, watching the vehicles cycle through 10 different auction blocks, at no longer than 45 seconds a pop. Over a collective din that drowns out the auctioneers, the dealers wink, nod or, for the less stealthy, raise a hand to indicate their bid.

headline.main: After Running Hot, Market for Used Cars Is Cooling

snippet: Images of a sauvignon blanc grape harvest in California’s Napa Valley — work that begins before the sun rises.
lead_paragraph: In the predawn chill of a September morning, Mario Bazán, his wife, Gloria, and their crew of about 10 workers arrived to harvest sauvignon blanc grapes grown on a plot near their Napa Valley home. Helping them in their work was a generator with bright lights attached, pulled by a tractor. On this morning, they harvested enough grapes to produce 220 cases of Mario Bazán Cellars wine. Picking the grapes in the early morning means that they are cooler when they go into the collection bins, which helps keep the sugars in ideal condition.

abstract: Will Power wins at an action-packed IndyCar season finale, and Jamie McMurray snags a Nascar Sprint Cup win after a yellow flag at Talladega.
snippet: Will Power wins at an action-packed IndyCar season finale, and Jamie McMurray snags a Nascar Sprint Cup win after a yellow flag at Talladega.
lead_paragraph: Will Power won the race, but by finishing fifth in Saturday’s 500-mile IndyCar season finale at Fontana, Calif., Scott Dixon clinched his third title in the series. Dixon, who also won the title in 2003 and 2008, had trailed Helio Castroneves in points much of this season. But a sixth-place finish in the race by Castroneves fell short of overcoming the 25-point lead Dixon held since the Houston double-header races earlier in the month.

abstract: Federal workers hit by the shutdown will be counted as employed in one Labor Department survey and unemployed in another, meaning a possible impact on the jobless rate but not the job growth figure.
snippet: Federal workers hit by the shutdown will be counted as employed in one Labor Department survey and unemployed in another, meaning a possible impact on the jobless rate but not the job growth figure.
lead_paragraph: There has been a lot of speculation about how the federal government shutdown will affect numbers for the October jobs report, due out Nov. 8. The jobs report is based on two different surveys — one of households, and one of employers — and it turns out that furloughed federal government workers will be treated as unemployed in the first survey but employed in the second. In other words, the temporary layoff of federal workers will probably increase the unemployment rate, but not (at least directly) depress the payroll job growth numbers.

headline.main: How the Furloughed Will Be Counted

abstract: This fall and winter, galleries are displaying art in a range of media, addressing an almost dizzying array of social and cultural issues — adolescent humor not included.
snippet: This fall and winter, galleries are displaying art in a range of media, addressing an almost dizzying array of social and cultural issues — adolescent humor not included.
lead_paragraph: TASTE in art is in constant flux. One season’s penchant for abstract paintings may be another’s fascination with chocolate Santas, or lead balloons, comic strips, or a less-is-more aesthetic. Steering through this weather are commercial galleries, in the thick of things, taking the art world’s pulse. Unlike museums, where exhibitions are planned years in advance, galleries can be more nimble, finalizing shows a couple of months ahead of time. Indeed, there is probably no better barometer of current collective rumblings than what’s being shown at the top New York and Los Angeles galleries.

headline.main: Galleries as the Art World’s Leading Indicators
headline.print_headline: Galleries as the Art World’s Leading Indicators

snippet: “Surrealism and the Rue Blomet,” at Eykyn Maclean gallery in New York, will focus on a building in Paris where Joan Miró and André Masson lived and worked in the 1920s.
lead_paragraph: IT has been 74 years since World War II fractured the Surrealist movement, forcing many of its artists to flee Europe for other parts of the globe. But now one of their earliest gathering spots in Paris will be resurrected, figuratively, in “Surrealism and the Rue Blomet,” from Friday through Dec. 13 at Eykyn Maclean gallery in New York.

headline.main: An Obscure Building Where Surrealism Thrived
headline.print_headline: An Obscure Building Where Surrealism Thrived

lead_paragraph: MOST curators strive for novelty when they are putting together an exhibition. Museums nearly always want to boast that a show is “the first,” “the largest,” “the longest” or “the fill-in-the-blank-est.” For the New-York Historical Society’s latest attraction, “The Armory Show at 100,” however, a measure of success is how closely its curators can recreate the experience of this seminal 1913 exhibition.

abstract: Advisers to the Food and Drug Administration unanimously voted in favor of a hepatitis C drug from Gilead Sciences.
snippet: Advisers to the Food and Drug Administration unanimously voted in favor of a hepatitis C drug from Gilead Sciences.
lead_paragraph: Advisers to the Food and Drug Administration unanimously voted in favor of a hepatitis C drug from Gilead Sciences. All 15 members of the agency’s panel of virus experts voted to recommend approval of Gilead’s pill, sofosbuvir, to treat several forms of the disease, which afflicts more than three million people in the United States. The agency is not required to adhere to the group’s advice, though it often does. Current treatments can take up to a year of therapy and cure only about three out of four patients. Gilead’s daily pill can cure up to 90 percent of patients infected with the most common form of the virus in just 12 weeks. Gilead, based in Foster City, Calif., is one of a half-dozen companies racing to develop more effective treatments for hepatitis C. The agency is expected to make a decision on the drug by Dec. 8.

headline.main: Tentative Approval for Faster-Acting Hepatitis C Drug

abstract: Via its Goldman Sachs Foundation, led by Dina Powell, the firm many associate with Wall Street greed and excess has staked out a position as one of the nation’s leading corporate philanthropists.
snippet: Via its Goldman Sachs Foundation, led by Dina Powell, the firm many associate with Wall Street greed and excess has staked out a position as one of the nation’s leading corporate philanthropists.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs is a master at making money. Lately it has become a master at giving it away. Goldman — for many a symbol of Wall Street greed and excess — wants the world to know it has a charitable side. With the same calculation that earned it a reputation as the savviest trading house on Wall Street, it has staked out a position as one of the nation’s leading corporate philanthropists, giving away more than $1.6 billion since 2008.

lead_paragraph: APPLE EARNINGS Apple has become one of the most valuable companies in the world largely because of the success of iPhones and iPads. But over the last year, the growth of its profit has slowed as fewer people have been upgrading their smartphones each year, and as more competitors have produced low-cost tablets. In response, Apple in September introduced not one, but two new iPhones. When the company announces its third-quarter earnings on Monday, investors and analysts will watch closely to determine whether the new iPhones have given Apple’s profit a much-needed lift.

lead_paragraph: I LOVE airports, hotels and anything involving getting from Point A to Point B. But it wasn’t always like that. When I first started out with Belvedere Vodka more than 10 years ago, business travel involved jumping on a train and going to places like Cambridge, Bristol or Exeter to talk to anyone who would listen to me talk about Belvedere. abstract: Dominating the feature film nominations were documentaries about issues and politics.
snippet: Dominating the feature film nominations were documentaries about issues and politics.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Issues and politics mostly ruled, as the International Documentary Association on Tuesday announced its nominees for its annual documentary awards. In the feature film category, nominations went to “The Act of Killing,” about Indonesian genocide; “Blackfish,” about orca whales in captivity; “Let the Fire Burn,” about a 1985 standoff between police and activists in Philadelphia; and “The Square,” about Egyptians struggling for social change. Those were joined by one very personal story, Sarah Polley’s “Stories We Tell,” about her discovery of a family secret that surrounded her own birth. The association also announced nominees for short films, television documentaries, and entries in other categories. The awards are to be presented at a ceremony in Los Angeles on Dec. 6.

headline.main: Documentary Association Announces Awards Nominations
